text: ANYONE: know anything abut Wubi?
sorry

ok, sorry, let me clarify. I have a wubi installation on an xp maching. everything was working fine, until, i just now did an update. it froze up in the middle of that. so i had to manually restart the computer. when i try to boot up now, i only have windows in grub
any way to get that back?

basically i have a folder in xp called ubuntu, and it has large files that are my ubuntu installation, but there is a folder called boot, which has a folder called grub, which is now empty. can i rebuild a 'grub' file in windows through notepad, that will bring this partition back alive?
or basically , i screwed the pooch?
You should be able to just add this to your boot.ini (add a new line to the end of the file):        c:\wubildr.mbr='Ubuntu'
You should be able to just add this to your boot.ini (add a new line to the end of the file):        c:\wubildr.mbr='Ubuntu'
so if that ini file is gone, can i create that in notepad, and add that line in? or do i need more data than that line?
To edit the boot.ini, 1: Right-click My Computer, and then click Properties. 2: On the Advanced tab, click Settings under Startup and Recovery.
3: Under System Startup, click Edit.  (from http://support.microsoft.com/kb/289022 )
that line is in that file from the instructions you just gave me.
I have a Wubi installation. so thats what the difference is
I created a blank file, with that line in it, and put it into the boot/grub folder in the dir created by the wubi installer. hoping that will solve on reboot
called it boot.ini, and added the line you told me to put in.

boot.ini is a windows configuration file, it's not contained in boot/grub or any wubi specific directory. It's in the root of the partition (but it's hidden and read only by default, so follow the instructions I gave to open it).
i did that and the line was already there.
I guess what i need then is what do i need to put into the boot/grub folder under the wubi directory to get the ubuntu option back when i boot up?
thats why im backing up the .disk files with all my settings and whatnot, then will reinstall wubi and replace the default .disk files with my old ones.
Odd. Can you take a picture of the menu(s) you see at boot?
sigh. no. it happened because i was updating, and it froze
No to what? You can't take a picture of the menus you see at boot?
i get the windows xp or Ubuntu
when i click ubuntu, there is no linux option in the grub loader
Ok. Can you boot an Ubuntu LiveCD?
the updates removed a lot of the files, and was going to install new files, but froze up. i had to hard restart
I have Helix 3
That's a problem within the root.dsk file, so re-installing won't help.
so is there a fix for this?
Yes, but it's hard to fix from within windows.
well, i have helix 3. its forensics tools built on ubuntu....will that work?
Yes.
ok, so im going to boot up to that, and then you can help me fix my wubi?
Yes.

You're welcome.

back. thanks again for your patience and time, and help. helix is up and running
Do you know how to mount partitions and how to loop mount files?

yeah its dev/hda1
are you there?
Yes.
ok just checking. what do i do now? lol
To mount your wubi root.disk run 'mount -o loop /mountpoint/ubuntu/disks/root.disk /mnt/'.
do that verbatim or substitube mountpoint with the actual mountpoint?
Substitute mountpoint.
/dev/hdb5 is not a mountpoint, it's a device node.
Run 'mount' to find where /dev/hdb5 is mounted.
media/hdb5?
that is doing something

hd stopped spinning, cursor still blinking on blank line.....nothing happening
i don't know what to do next? nothing happened on that command, the cursor went to another line, and blinks....nothing going on.
Does pressing ctrl+D do anything?
hd starts spinning again
and nothing.....

No idea. The output of 'dmesg' (in another terminal) would be usefull, but it's too much to type out manually. Can you connect to the internet or transfer the output via flash drive to a computer that can?
many many lines of 'failed to read'
it connects to the internet
im confused? pastebin?

You're liveCD is too old then.

Sorry it took longer than I expected. I'm back now.
i have the live cd up in command prompt, as root. the 'mount' command does not list the partition with wubi
Run 'mkdir /media/windows' then 'mount /dev/sdXY /media/windows' (replacing 'XY' with the proper values from blkid).
DONE
now mount that?
Now run 'mkdir /media/wubi/' then  'mount -o loop /media/windows/ubuntu/disks/root.disk /media/wubi/'.
done
Now run 'mount --bind /proc/ /media/wubi/proc; mount --bind /dev/ /media/wubi/dev/; mount --bind /sys/ /media/wubi/sys/'.
error messages.....mount point media/wubi/proc does not exsist, same for /dev and /sys....with the same beginning
need to create those mount points first?
how do i do that?
Those directories should already exist.
they exist, but the mount points don't exist on this live cd, its from another system
/dev /proc and /sys don't exist in the LiveCD environment?
just need the command to add mount points for those directories, then the binds should work
i mean '/media/wubi/proc' '/media/wibi/dev' and '/media/wubi/sys' do not exist on the live cd
Then something is wrong.
What is the ouput of 'mount'?
LOL thats what i mean....i was updating, and it froze, the updates removed a lot of stuff, and then didnt get to install the replacements
I find it hard to believe that an update would remove any of those directories.

and dev/loop1 on /mnt type ext4 (rw)
can u just tell me the command to create these mnt points? and i will try to run the bind command again...? just humor me
No.
no?
You mounted to /mnt/, I said to mount to /media/wubi. That's what's causing the problem.
ok so what do i do?
sorry. please help me get this right. i thought i typed in exactly what you told me to
i did mkdir /media/wubi
Run 'mount --bind /proc/ /mnt/proc; mount --bind /dev/ /mnt/dev/; mount --bind /sys/ /mnt/sys/'.
mount point /mnt/dev does not exsist
mkdir /mnt/dev?
No.
Let's try mounting the root.disk again. Run 'sudo umount /mnt/' then 'mount -o loop /media/windows/ubuntu/disks/root.disk /media/wubi/'.
DONE
now the bind command again?
Ok, now please run 'mount' and pastebin the full output. It would help if you could connect this machine to the internet and pastebin directly from there.

ok just did aptget on pastebinit
so now you want mount | pastebinit?
ok url is http://pastebin.com/Zx6Z24Jc
like that?
what happened to you? i finally understood the pastebinit and gave u my url!

url is /Zx6Z24Jc

this stress makes me need to smoke another cigarette....will you be here still? i will be quick. im trying everything you tell me
i figured out the pastebinit
Yes.
I will seriously send you money if you can get my wubi back!
i am back
did i do the pastebin correctly? and does that help?
Yes and yes.
Run 'umount /mnt/' then 'mount -o loop /media/windows/ubuntu/disks/root.disk /media/wubi/' then run 'mount | pastebinit' and give the URL.
sweet. sorry to be a nuisance. you really are a great soul for doing this. THANK you again. i really will send you money if you get this going for me.

Try running 'cd' first.
can i force this to quit?
still says buys
Try 'fuser -k /mnt/'
that was successful, don't know what it did
It killed any processes with open files in /mnt/. Now try 'umount /mnt/' again (if you haven't already).
still buys
still busy i mean
Run 'umount /mnt/dev/; umount /mnt/proc/; umount /mnt/sys/; umount /mnt/'
mnt/dev not mounted /mnt still busy
Did you forget the leading '/' in 'umount /mnt/dev/'?
nope i put in all the slashes you put in
Try running 'sudo umount -a'.
ok mnt is no longer mounted!
now the loop command?
Ok. Now run 'mount /dev/sdXY /media/windows/' (again, replacing XY with the proper values).
done
Now run 'mount -o loop /media/windows/ubuntu/disks/root.disk /media/wubi/'
DONE
Now run 'mkdir /media/wubi/media/windows/' (I know that seems odd, but I mean exactly what I typed).
DONE
Now run 'mount --bind /media/windows/ /media/wubi/media/windows/'. Then run 'mount | pastebinit' and give the URL.
http://pastebin.com/VcnWxQmw
Not that it should be a problem, but did you really install XP to a fat32 partition rather than ntfs?
no its ntfs that is just a data partition that was shared on linux and xp
the NEWSHARE partition is where wubi is at, but it worked fine
i mean, the windows is installed on an ntfs partition, but the newshare partition is fat, used for data files that are shared on both OSs
and that wubi is installed on the newshare partition
hope that makes sense

Ahh, installing wubi to a separate partition from 'C:' is probably the root cause of the problem. Wubi is currently embarassingly bad at dealing with being installed to a different partition than 'C:'. You are lucky you're still able to boot windows in fact.
it was working fine forever, with no problems. it only started today when i ran updates, and it froze up
We'll continue with what I was planning to do, but there may be additional problems I wasn't expecting because it's a separate partition.
can we just TRY to repair it as if it were on C:, now that we got the partition mounted...PLEASE just try.

is there a slash after the second proc?

successful
Now run 'chroot /media/wubi/'.

You need a 64 bit liveCD :(

First run 'chmod +w /media/wubi/boot/grub/grub.cfg'.
DONE
Now run 'ls -l /media/wubi/boot/ | pastebinit' and 'blkid | pastebinit'.

It is, and that's the problem. I'm trying to see if I can rebuild the initrd with vfat support now. If that fails, you should be still be able to backup your current root.disk, re-install wubi, then copy /boot/ from the new root.disk to the old one, and restore the old root.disk.

It's not a directory, it's a single file.
sudo mount -o loop /host/ubuntu/disks/root.disk.bak /mnt/
sudo mv /mnt/boot/ /mnt/boot-bak2; sudo cp -r /boot/ /mnt/
sudo umount /mnt/; sudo mv /host/ubuntu/disks/root.disk /host/ubuntu/disks/root.disk.new; sudo mv /host/ubuntu/disks/root.disk.bak /host/ubuntu/disks/root.disk
